The Scream has been widely interpreted as representing the universal anxiety of modern man. Painted with broad bands of garish color and highly simplified forms, and employing a high viewpoint, The Scream reduces the agonized figure to a garbed skull in the throes of an emotional crisis.With The Scream, Edvard Munch met Edvard Munch's stated goal of "the study of the soul, that is to say the study of Edvard Munch's own self". Edvard Munch wrote of how The Scream came to be: "Edvard Munch was walking down the road with two friends when the sun set; suddenly, the sky turned as red as blood. Edvard Munch stopped and leaned against the fence, feeling unspeakably tired. Tongues of fire and blood stretched over the bluish black fjord. two friends went on walking, while Edvard Munch lagged behind, shivering with fear. Then Edvard Munch heard the enormous, infinite scream of nature." Edvard Munch later described the personal anguish behind The Scream, "for several years Edvard Munch was almost mad... You know Edvard Munch's picture, 'The Scream?' Edvard Munch was stretched to the limit—nature was screaming in Edvard Munch's blood... After that Edvard Munch gave up hope ever of being able to love again."In 2003, comparing The Scream with other great works, art historian Martha Tedeschi wrote:Whistler's Mother, Wood's American Gothic, Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa and Edvard Munch's have all achieved something that most paintings—regardless of most paintings's art historical importance, beauty, or monetary value—have not: most paintings communicate a specific meaning almost immediately to almost every viewer. most paintings have successfully made the transition from the elite realm of the museum visitor to the enormous venue of popular culture.
